text: Ye mountains, that ye skipped like rams; and ye little hills, like lambs ?
text_kjv: Ye mountains, that ye skipped like rams; and ye little hills, like lambs ?
text_niv: you mountains, that you skipped like rams,you hills, like lambs?
text_esv: O mountains, that you skip like rams? O hills, like lambs?
text_nlt: Why, mountains, did you skip like rams?Why, hills, like lambs?
text_msg: And mountains, why did you skip like rams?and you, hills, frolic like spring lambs?
text_nasb: O mountains, that you skip like rams? O hills, like lambs?
context: Psalm 114 is a hymn celebrating the Exodus, Israel's liberation from slavery in Egypt. Understanding the Exodus is crucial to grasping the verse. The Exodus wasn't just a historical event; it was Yahweh's definitive act of redemption, solidifying his covenant with Israel and demonstrating his power over the gods of Egypt. The parting of the Red Sea, the plagues, and the giving of the Law at Mount Sinai were all pivotal moments. The Psalmist uses vivid imagery and hyperbole to convey the awe and wonder inspired by God's interventions. The psalm doesn't merely recount events; it aims to evoke an emotional and spiritual response. It aims to inspire faith and trust in the same God who delivered their ancestors. The personification of nature – the sea fleeing, the Jordan turning back, the mountains skipping – highlights God's dominion over creation. This was a powerful message, especially for a people who had witnessed firsthand the immense power of the Egyptian empire and its deities who were tied to nature and the Nile River. Remembering this act of divine intervention would have been vital to retaining faith and the national identity of the Israelites.
meaning: Psalm 114:6, "Ye mountains, that ye skipped like rams; and ye little hills, like lambs?" uses personification to portray the natural world reacting to God's presence and power during the Exodus. The mountains and hills, typically symbols of stability and immovability, are depicted as leaping and bounding, emphasizing the magnitude of God's intervention. This isn't meant to be taken literally, but as a poetic device to communicate the sheer impact of God's presence. Rams and lambs were both familiar animals; rams are known for their strength and agile leaping while lambs evoke images of gentle agility. The different animals attributed to mountains versus the hills might reflect a distinction in the size and power they represent. The mountains skipped like Rams, a display of powerful, sudden movement, while the hills like lambs, with lighter gentler movement, showing all creation reacting to God’s presence. The fleeing of the sea and the turning back of the Jordan River, mentioned earlier in the psalm, further amplify this theme of nature responding to God's command. This suggests that God's power is so great that even the most steadfast aspects of the earth are affected by his presence. This verse is a powerful theological statement about God's sovereignty and control over creation. The whole earth trembles at his presence (Psalm 97:5, Psalm 99:1).
application: Psalm 114:6 has profound applications for modern life. First, it encourages us to recognize God's presence and power in our own lives, even when circumstances seem insurmountable. Just as the mountains skipped at God's command during the Exodus, we can trust that God is able to move the seemingly immovable obstacles in our lives. This verse inspires hope and reminds us that no challenge is too great for God to overcome. Second, this verse challenges us to consider how we react to God's presence. Do we, like the mountains and hills, respond with joyful acknowledgement of his power and authority? Or are we resistant to his influence, clinging to our own will and control? We can make our own lives an Exodus; following God’s guidance, even if it means wandering in the wilderness for a while. Third, the verse reminds us to be attentive to the wonders of creation. God's power is evident in the natural world, from the smallest lamb to the tallest mountain. By appreciating the beauty and complexity of creation, we can gain a deeper understanding of God's character and his love for us. This encourages environmental stewardship and a sense of responsibility towards the planet. Fourth, this verse calls us to trust in God's deliverance, even in the face of fear and uncertainty. The Israelites faced immense challenges during the Exodus, but God remained faithful to his promise of liberation. Similarly, we can rely on God's faithfulness in our own lives, knowing that he will never abandon us. This psalm can be used as a personal statement of faith in times of trouble, reaffirming belief in God's promise of protection and guidance.
prayer: Heavenly Father, your power is beyond our comprehension, able to move mountains and part seas. Forgive us for the times we doubt your presence and limit your ability to work in our lives. Open our eyes to the wonders of your creation and help us to recognize your hand at work in every aspect of our lives. Grant us the faith to trust in your deliverance, even when we face seemingly insurmountable challenges. May we respond to your presence with joyful obedience, recognizing your authority and surrendering our will to yours. Help us become more aware of our responsibility to the planet, and to you, as the source of life. Guide us on the path to your promise land. In Jesus' name, we pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: The image of 'skipping' isn't literal but figurative. It powerfully conveys the magnitude of God's power, implying that even the most stable aspects of creation react to His presence. It represents the disruption and awe that accompanied God's intervention during the Exodus.

faqs.answer: The difference in the animals likely represents the relative size and strength of the mountains versus the hills. Rams suggest powerful, sudden movement and the hills like lambs, with lighter gentler movement, showing all creation reacting to God’s presence.
